item.title: China Gives EU Business Groups High-Level Meetings to Boost Ties
item.description: China is giving European business leaders its warmest welcome in years, in an effort to strengthen ties as Beijing seeks to counter Donald Trump’s tariff pressure and stabilize its slowing economy.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Choong Wilkins, Colum Murphy, Jing Li

item.title: SALT Agreement Remains Elusive for House GOP on Trump Tax Bill
item.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson emerged from a late-night meeting Monday with holdout Republicans from New York and other high-tax states saying they had made “lots of progress” on a deal over the divisive state and local tax deduction.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Jack Fitzpatrick

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson speaks to the media as he arrives at the US Capitol on May 19. Photographer: Alex Wong/Getty Images

item.title: China Accuses US of Undermining Trade Talks With Warnings Against Huawei Chips
item.description: The Chinese government accused the Trump administration of undermining recent trade talks in Geneva after it warned that using Huawei Technologies Co.’s artificial-intelligence chips “anywhere in the world” would violate US export controls.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Tam, Debby Wu

media:content.media:description: A corporate logo sits on a Huawei Technologies Co. NetEngine 8000 intelligent metro router on display during a 5G event in London, U.K., on Thursday, Feb. 20, 2020. Huawei said at the event it currently has 91 contracts for 5G, with 47 of those in Europe.

item.title: Thailand Eyes $15 Billion Cut in US Trade Gap With Export Rules
item.description: Thailand expects to reduce its trade gap with the US by as much as $15 billion annually with its recent initiatives to prevent the misuse of origin rules for exports, according to Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

item.title: Australia’s Liberal-National Coalition Splits After Decades
item.description: Australia’s decades-long Liberal-National tie-up will end after the leader of the National Party, David Littleproud, said his party won’t form another coalition agreement with the Liberal Party.
item.dc:creator: Keira Wright

media:content.media:description: Peter Dutton, right, shakes hands with David Littleproud at Parliament House in 2022. Photographer: Martin Ollman/Getty Images AsiaPac

item.title: Taiwan Plans Wealth Fund to Counter China With Global Expansion
item.description: Taiwan President Lai Ching-te said his government would set up a sovereign wealth fund to help the archipelago’s companies expand globally, a move that would expand Taipei’s ties to markets around the world and counter China’s attempts to isolate it.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Betty Hou

media:content.media:description: Lai Ching-te speaks in Taipei on May 20.

item.title: India Expects Multi-Phase Trade Deal With US as Talks Proceed
item.description: India is discussing a US trade deal structured in three tranches and expects to reach an interim agreement before July, when President Donald Trump’s reciprocal tariffs are set to kick in, according to officials in New Delhi familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava, Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump, right, and Narendra Modi in February.

item.title: Japan’s Kato Plans Bessent Meet to Discuss Topics Including FX
item.description: Japan’s Finance Minister said he’s arranging a bilateral meeting with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent this week to discuss topics including currency matters, triggering further gains in the yen.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Katsunobu Kato Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan Minister’s Brag About Free Rice Misfires Amid Surging Prices
item.description: Japan’s agriculture minister said he’d been inconsiderate after comments about his plentiful supply of free rice struck a nerve with the public, who face soaring prices in stores.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hilton

media:content.media:description: A customer shops for rice at a supermarket in Koshigaya, Japan.

item.title: Taiwan’s Lai Toughens China Stance, Stoking Debate on Democracy
item.description: As President Lai Ching-te marks his first year in office, he’s sending a stark warning to the people of Taiwan: If you say anything that threatens the archipelago’s security, there will be consequences.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee, Cindy Wang, Miaojung Lin

media:content.media:description: Lai Ching-te Photographer: An Rong Xu/Bloomberg

item.title: Stablecoin Bill Advances in US Senate in Big Win for Crypto
item.description: Stablecoin legislation overcame a procedural blockade in the US Senate, marking a major victory for the crypto industry after a group of Democrats dropped their opposition Monday.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

item.title: NJ Congresswoman Charged With Assault in ICE Protest, Prosecutor Says
item.description: The Justice Department charged a Democratic House lawmaker from Newark, New Jersey, with assault after a confrontation with US immigration officers on May 9 at a private detention center that is central to President Donald Trump’s plans for mass deportations, a prosecutor said.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Chris Strohm, Ellen M Gilmer

media:content.media:description: LaMonica McIver Photographer:Tom Williams/CQ-Roll Call, Inc/Getty Images

item.title: US Offers $10 Million for Tips on Hezbollah in Latin America
item.description: The US Department of State is offering a reward of up to $10 million for information on Hezbollah’s activities and connections in Latin America.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Carvalho

media:content.media:description: Photo by Mohammed HUWAIS / AFP) (Photo by MOHAMMED HUWAIS/AFP via Getty Images) Photographer: MOHAMMED HUWAIS/AFP

item.title: France, UK, Canada Call on Israel to Allow More Aid to Gaza
item.description: The leaders of France, Britain and Canada called on Israel to stop its military operations in Gaza and allow humanitarian aid to enter the territory.
item.dc:creator: Frank Connelly

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians collect cooked food from a community food kitchen in Jabaliya, northern Gaza, on Monday, May 19, 2025. International pressure has mounted on Israel to restart aid.

item.title: Rich Americans Ready to Swoop In If New Zealand Relaxes Home-Buying Ban
item.description: Wealthy Americans eying New Zealand as a haven are hoping the government will soon relax a ban on house sales to foreigners, according to advisers.
item.dc:creator: Ainsley Thomson

media:content.media:description: Lake Wakatipu in Queenstown. Photographer: Birgit Krippner/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Plans to Rally House Republicans Divided on Tax Cut Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump plans to go to the Capitol on Tuesday to urge fractious House Republicans to overcome divisions and unite behind his signature tax-cut legislation.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Ken Tran

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump walks on the South Lawn of the White House after arriving on Marine One in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, May 4, 2025. Trump announced Sunday that he plans to impose a 100% tariff on films produced overseas, extending his restrictive trade policies on US imports to the entertainment sector for the first time.

item.title: Trump Hands Putin Win With Retreat From Ukraine Peace Talks
item.description: Eleven days ago, European leaders took heart when President Donald Trump called for a 30-day ceasefire in Ukraine and threatened new sanctions on Russia. A telephone call with Vladimir Putin on Monday revealed those hopes were misplaced.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi, Courtney McBride

media:content.media:description: This combination photo shows President Donald Trump in a business roundtable, May 16, 2025, in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates, left, and Russian President Vladimir Putin at a signing ceremony at the Kremlin in Moscow, May 10, 2025. (AP Photo) AP

item.title: Chicago Mayor’s Hiring Practices Probed by Justice Department
item.description: The US Department of Justice said it will investigate whether Chicago is discriminating against municipal job candidates by race after Mayor Brandon Johnson highlighted the number of Black officials in his administration while addressing a church on the city’s south side.
item.dc:creator: Miranda Davis

media:content.media:description: Brandon Johnson

item.title: US Court Orders Return of Another Deportee From El Salvador
item.description: The Trump administration was ordered by an appeals court to facilitate the return of a Venezuelan man who was deported to a maximum-security prison in El Salvador — at least the second time the administration has been told to bring back a migrant it wrongly removed.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A prison officer stands guard in the watchtower at maximum security penitentiary CECOT in Tecoluca, El Salvador, on April 4. Photographer: Alex Peña/Getty Images

item.title: Supreme Court Lets Trump End Venezuelan Migrant Protections
item.description: The Supreme Court let the Trump administration end legal protections for 350,000 Venezuelans, stripping them of the right to temporarily live and work in the US and opening many of them to the prospect of deportation.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: The US Supreme Court in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, March 4, 2025. Donald Trump's primetime address Tuesday night from Capitol Hill, billed as a chronicle of his "Renewal of the American Dream," comes at a critical juncture early in his second term, as voters who elected him to tackle inflation and improve the economy are beginning to weigh the impact of his agenda.

item.title: Senator Asks SEC to Probe Firms Advising Against JBS Listing
item.description: Kentucky Senator Rand Paul has asked the top US securities regulator to probe two major firms that have advised their clients to vote against a proposed New York listing by JBS SA, the world’s largest meat producer.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr

media:content.media:description: Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky and chairman of the Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee, during a confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Troy Edgar, a Navy veteran and former mayor of Los Alamitos, California, served as DHS’s chief financial officer during Trump’s first term, overseeing the department’s more than $90 billion budget and its workforce. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: FDA Names Acting Leaders for Inspections, Tobacco Regulation
item.description: US Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Marty Makary named agency veterans to lead tobacco regulation and inspections, two high-profile areas, according to documents seen by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang

media:content.media:description: Martin Makary, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), speaks during a news conference in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, May 12, 2025. Trump is attempting to slash drug prices for Americans by more closely aligning their costs to lower prices paid abroad, renewing and expanding upon a failed push from his first term.

item.title: Harvard President Seeks Alumni Help to Boost Case Against Trump
item.description: Harvard University President Alan Garber is asking alumni who want to support the school in its standoff with the Trump administration for three things: their attention, their voices and their money.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Alan Garber Photographer: Craig F. Walker/Boston Globe/Getty Images

item.title: Assessing the Outlook for Trump’s ‘Big, Beautiful Bill’
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Every Monday, Bloomberg Intelligence senior analyst Nathan Dean gives his insights into what’s been happening and what’s coming up in the nooks and crannies of government and markets. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Nathan R Dean

item.title: Stablecoin Fight Heads to Showdown as Senate Democrats Splinter
item.description: The Senate is poised to advance industry-backed stablecoin legislation in a key vote expected Monday evening, with a group of crypto-friendly Democrats led by Kirsten Gillibrand and Angela Alsobrooks seeking to end their party’s blockade of one of President Donald Trump’s top priorities.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Kirsten Gillibrand at DC Blockchain Summit on March 26.

item.title: Warren Questions Pilgrim’s Pride, JBS Over $5 Million Trump Donation
item.description: Democratic Senator Elizabeth Warren queried chicken producer Pilgrim’s Pride Corp. and its parent company JBS USA over the meat processor’s donation to Donald Trump’s Inaugural Committee.
item.dc:creator: Gerson Freitas Jr, Gabriella Borter

media:content.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren, a Democrat from Massachusetts and ranking member of Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee, during a confirmation hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Senators on both sides of the panel are likely to ask how Michelle Bowman plans to comply with an executive order that curbs the power of independent agencies, and are eager to hear how she will approach a plan that would require the country's largest lenders to hold significantly more capital to buffer against losses and a financial crisis.

item.title: Trump Signs Bill Cracking Down on Deepfake Revenge Porn
item.description: President Donald Trump signed a bill to force social media companies to remove non-consensual sharing of explicit sexual imagery online, calling it a “horribly wrong” situation.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Hadriana Lowenkron

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, alongside First Lady Melania Trump, signs the "Take It Down Act" during a bill signing ceremony in the Rose Garden of the White House in Washington, DC, on May 19, 2025. The bipartisan legislation will criminalize the non-consenual publication of sexual imagery, including AI-generated deepfakes and "revenge porn." (Photo by Jim WATSON / AFP) (Photo by JIM WATSON/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Trump Says Ukraine, Russia to Start Truce Talks Immediately
item.description: President Donald Trump said that Moscow and Kyiv would begin talks “immediately” on ending the war in Ukraine after a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin, Donald Trump

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel to Take Over All Gaza, Start Aid Flows
item.description: Israel will take over the entire Gaza Strip, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday, as the military announced it would carry out an “unprecedented attack” on Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Alisa Odenheimer, Ethan Bronner, Galit Altstein

item.title: EU’s €150 Billion Defense Fund Receives Preliminary Approval
item.description: The European Union’s 27 member states gave initial approval to a €150 billion ($169 billion) defense fund that will distribute money to countries looking to invest in security capabilities such as ammunition, drones and the protection of critical infrastructure, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: Caesar self-propelled howitzer cannon assembly at a factory in France.
